intro: Humata trukensis, commonly known as the Truk Island humata, is a rare flowering plant native to the Caroline Islands. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, palm-like leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and is adapted to saline and sandy soils. Its blooming period occurs during the dry season, and it plays a significant role in the local ecosystem. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
